race.name: Hungry Bear 100
race.tagline: Northern Wisconsin century in the Chequamegon area.

climate.description: Variable summer conditions. Potential for heat or rain.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through northern Wisconsin Chequamegon area. Rolling to hilly terrain with moderate to significant elevation.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional Wisconsin century in Chequamegon area. Better infrastructure than some Northwoods events.

biased_opinion.summary: Hungry Bear 100 offers a 100-mile gravel challenge in Wisconsin's Chequamegon area, known for mountain biking and outdoor recreation. Cable has better amenities than typical Northwoods towns, and the terrain is rolling to hilly with good scenery. It's a regional event with modest field depth, but the Chequamegon setting adds appeal for Wisconsin cyclists.
strengths: Better amenities than some remote events
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional 100-miler in a beautiful Wisconsin setting. Better than some remote Northwoods events due to Cable's tourism infrastructure. Worth it for Wisconsin cyclists, but not a destination race for distant travelers.

final_verdict.one_liner: Regional Wisconsin century in the Chequamegon area with good terrain.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Wisconsin or the Upper Midwest and want a 100-miler in a beautiful setting‚Äîyes. If you're traveling from far away‚Äîprobably not worth the trip.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Wisconsin events: Chequamegon (mountain bike), Driftless Gravel. For similar regional centuries: other Midwest gravel events.

logistics.airport: Duluth (DLH) or Minneapolis (MSP) ~2-3 hours, Milwaukee (MKE) 4 hours
logistics.lodging_strategy: Cable has lodging due to Chequamegon area tourism. Book early during summer season.
logistics.food: Small town with dining options. Better than typical Northwoods towns.
logistics.packet_pickup: Typically day before or race morning
logistics.parking: parking at Cable Municipal Parking implied[3]

history.origin_story: Gravel century in Wisconsin's Chequamegon area.

course_description.character: Rolling to hilly Northwoods gravel through Chequamegon area.
course_description.signature_challenge: 100-mile distance on rolling to hilly Northwoods terrain.

non_negotiables.why: 4500 feet of climbing requires good aerobic capacity.

topics.climbing: Pacing for rolling to hilly terrain

marketplace_variables.race_hook: 100 miles of Chequamegon area Northwoods gravel.
marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Regional Wisconsin century with 4500 feet of climbing.

logistics.explanation: Dan from One On One Bicycle Studio missed the start "for the second year in a row" and "didn't care" - that low-stress approach masks basic organizational gaps. Packet pickup happens at Tilly's Pies with free coffee, which sounds charming but hardly screams professional logistics for 800+ riders spread across three different start locations and times.

length.explanation: 100 miles through Wisconsin Northwoods delivers proper sufferfest territory, as competitive rider Dan discovered: "Rock Lake Road and Camp Road 38 make up the infamous finishing stretch" with "around 2k feet of elevation in those punchy, sandy hills" packed into the final 25 miles. Only "a handful of people" exceeded 9 hours, suggesting achievable but demanding distance. Longer than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

technicality.explanation: Most of the route runs on "perfect, small crushed stone" until mile 75 when conditions deteriorate dramatically. One rider notes the final stretch becomes "exclusively sand...and big rocks" where Scott got three flats in quick succession at mile 95. The 2.5-mile ATV Trail connector offers muddy technical challenge, but overall it's accessible gravel racing. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: 4,500 feet over 100 miles concentrates into "quick, punchy hills and descents" rather than sustained climbing. The final 25 miles pack "around 2k feet of elevation" into sandy, rocky terrain that one competitive rider warned others to "save something in the tank for." It's rolling Northwoods punishment that accumulates without destroying your day. Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds.

climate.explanation: Early May weather creates planning challenges, as Dan's group discovered when they "underdressed for the day" after waking to 34¬∞F despite forecasts "promising sun and temps over 50." The sun finally appeared and temps "just reached up above 50 degrees," but that morning surprise shows why northern Wisconsin spring racing requires weather contingency planning. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Cable, Wisconsin sits around 1,400-1,600 feet - basically sea level for anyone not living in a swamp. Zero altitude considerations for training, travel, or performance impact. This is pure Midwest flatland elevation that won't affect your breathing or pacing strategy. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds ‚Äî no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Parker's course design "winds its way deep into the north woods" through forest service roads where "you're rarely traveling in the same direction for long." Linda Shydlowski felt "gratitude for the sunshine, blue skies, forests, lakes, rivers" during her ride. The route offers "6 or 7 hours" through Chequamegon forest with limited cell service, creating proper backcountry isolation.

prestige.explanation: Dan epitomizes the race culture: missing the start twice running because "fun and adventure always trump competition." Tim Savre won in 4:40:58, but the emphasis stays on inclusivity over racing pedigree. One rider loved "how chill this race was" and called it "the antithesis to so many amped up races," confirming this isn't a resume-building competitive showcase.

race_quality.explanation: Race director Dave Schlabowske emphasizes the "family reunion feel" but basic organization shows gaps - no official aid stations despite listing them at miles 26 and 67, limited cellular coverage for emergency support, and self-supported format where "we will not come help you if you call." The DIY charm comes with operational limitations for 800 riders.

experience.explanation: Post-race scene centers on Tilly's Pies, Ursa Minor Brewing beers, and Rivers Eatery with "ski and bike jerseys from famous pros" covering the walls. Monica Shoberg shaved three hours off her previous time, showing the course rewards returning riders. One participant praised "the people, the pie, the pizza, hanging out on the patio after the race" as the perfect celebration atmosphere.

community.explanation: Proceeds support Cable Volunteer Fire Department, Steve Tilford Foundation, and local scholarships, creating lasting community impact. The "family reunion feel" includes 11-year-old Molly Ehlers completing the 60-miler with her dad Aaron. One rider appreciated skipping "age group prizes, podiums" to "keep registration fees low" while maintaining the welcoming grassroots atmosphere that brings groups back annually.

field_depth.explanation: Elite winner Tim Savre finished in 4:40:58, but the competitive depth stays shallow in this 800-rider field focused on adventure over racing. The culture celebrates riders like Dan who miss starts without caring, and families completing courses together. Limited cell coverage and no support structure discourage serious racers seeking fast, competitive fields. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100. As D Rider puts it: "Typically I like to start fast and just hang with the lead group as long as possible and see where it goes from there."

value.explanation: The DIY approach that skips "age group prizes, podiums" keeps "registration fees low" while supporting multiple local causes with race proceeds. Norske Nook serves pre-race "potato pancakes, bacon, eggs, and lingonberry jam," and post-race pie orders create affordable celebration options. Three distance options provide choice without premium pricing typical of destination gravel events.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $70-110. Small-town Cable, Wisconsin keeps lodging and dining costs reasonable compared to resort destinations. Pre-race breakfast at Norske Nook offers hearty "potato pancakes" and "lingonberry jam" at local prices, while post-race scenes at Rivers Eatery and Tilly's Pies avoid premium event catering. The low-key Northwoods setting delivers affordable gravel racing without tourist destination markup. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: Hungry Bear 100 mile Gravel bike racing in Cable Wisconsin. Bike, Salsa Cutthroat
videos.description: Hungry bear 100 gravel bike race starts and ends in Cable Wi. There's also a shorter 60 mile race. The Salsa Cutthroat on 2.2 Teravails came in handy at mile 80 when the roads turned into rocky Sand for nearly 8 miles.

videos.title: Hungry Bear Gravel Race Cable, WI 2024

quotes.text: At mile 80 we hit sand patches for about 6.8 miles it was just unbelievable. The Salsa Cutthroat on 2.2 Teravails came in handy when the roads turned into rocky sand for nearly 8 miles.

It feels like being out west in Montana - the landscape here, the trees. It was really good course, the majority of the ride was really good, some steep hills obviously, but the course here is pretty sandy.
